Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an attack on free speech and democracy.
The bill grants excessive powers to the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) and exempts the government from accountability.
Existing laws are deemed sufficient to address criminal activities, human trafficking, child exploitation, and hate speech.
The bill could lead to government censorship of political opponents and any information questioning government narratives.
Historical examples, such as misinformation about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, are cited as reasons for needing more government accountability, not less.
The COVID-19 pandemic is used as an example where censorship of information, later proven true, caused harm.
Notable Quotes: This Bill must NEVER be introduced. It is utterly totalitarian in nature.
It is outright dangerous to bestow to any body the right to determine 'what is true' and to censor anyone who may question the accuracy of government information.
Free speech is the fertilizer of democracy. Suppression of free speech is the building block of totalitarianism.
